Molten salts: Potential candidates for thermal energy storage applications - Bhatnagar - 2022 - International Journal of Energy Research - Wiley Online Library International Journal of Energy Research Volume 46, Issue 13 pp. 17755-17785 REVIEW PAPER Full Access Molten salts: Potential candidates for thermal energy storage applications Pranshul Bhatnagar , Pranshul Bhatnagar Department of Chemical Engineering, BITS Pilani Hyderabad Campus, Hyderabad, India Search for more papers by this author Sufiyan Siddiqui , Sufiyan Siddiqui Department of Chemical Engineering, BITS Pilani Hyderabad Campus, Hyderabad, India Search for more papers by this author Inkollu Sreedhar , Corresponding Author Inkollu Sreedhar [email protected] orcid.org/0000-0003-1706-5735 Department of Chemical Engineering, BITS Pilani Hyderabad Campus, Hyderabad, India Correspondence Inkollu Sreedhar, Department of Chemical Engineering, BITS Pilani Hyderabad Campus, Hyderabad 500078, India. Email: [email protected] Search for more papers by this author Rajagopalan Parameshwaran , Rajagopalan Parameshwaran orcid.org/0000-0003-3906-1081 Department of Mechanical Engineering, BITS Pilani Hyderabad Campus, Hyderabad, India Search for more papers by this author Pranshul Bhatnagar , Pranshul Bhatnagar Department of Chemical Engineering, BITS Pilani Hyderabad Campus, Hyderabad, India Search for more papers by this author Sufiyan Siddiqui , Sufiyan Siddiqui Department of Chemical Engineering, BITS Pilani Hyderabad Campus, Hyderabad, India Search for more papers by this author Inkollu Sreedhar , Corresponding Author Inkollu Sreedhar [email protected] orcid.org/0000-0003-1706-5735 Department of Chemical Engineering, BITS Pilani Hyderabad Campus, Hyderabad, India Correspondence Inkollu Sreedhar, Department of Chemical Engineering, BITS Pilani Hyderabad Campus, Hyderabad 500078, India. Email: [email protected] Search for more papers by this author Rajagopalan Parameshwaran , Rajagopalan Parameshwaran orcid.org/0000-0003-3906-1081 Department of Mechanical Engineering, BITS Pilani Hyderabad Campus, Hyderabad, India Search for more papers by this author First published: 25 July 2022 https://doi.org/10.1002/er.8441 Citations: 73 Get it at Duke Funding information: BITS Pilani; Council of Scientific and Industrial Research, India, Grant/Award Number: 22(0783)/19/EMR-II Summary Molten salts as thermal energy storage (TES) materials are gaining the attention of researchers worldwide due to their attributes like low vapor pressure, non-toxic nature, low cost and flexibility, high thermal stability, wide range of applications etc. This review presents potential applications of molten salts in solar and nuclear TES and the factors influencing their performance. Ternary salts (Hitec salt, Hitec XL) are found to be best suited for concentrated solar plants due to their lower melting point and higher efficiency. Two-tank direct energy storage system is found to be more economical due to the inexpensive salts (KCl-MgCl 2 ), while thermoclines are found to be more thermally efficient due to the power cycles involved and the high volumetric heat capacity of the salts involved (LiF-NaF-KF). Heat storage density has been given special focus in this review and methods to increase the same in terms of salt composition changes are discussed in the paper. Methods of concatenating energy storage systems with nuclear power plants are also discussed with different types of nuclear reactors like MHTGR, PAHTR, VHTR, etc. Nanomodifications of molten salts are done to improve heat transfer properties and efficiency of the transfer. The best dopants for such modifications were found to be TiO 2 , SiO 2 , MWCNTs, etc. Future challenges for large scale deployment of molten salts viz., high volume expansion ratio, low thermal conductivity, incongruent melting, corrosion, etc., are listed and discussed. Corrosion of molten salts and its mitigation has been discussed in detail for developing next-generation storage systems and its remedies are also discussed. Abbreviations ARE aircraft reactor experiment CNG compressed natural gas CSP concentrated solar power CSPP concentrated solar power plant DSC differential scanning calorimetry ESD energy storage density ESE energy storage efficiency ESS energy storage systems HTF heat transfer fluid HTR high temperature reactor LATES liquid adsorption thermal energy storage LCOE levelized cost of electricity LF line focusing LHTS latent heat thermal storage LW-SMR light water-small modular reactor MHTGR modular high-temperature gas-cooled reactor MSR molten salt reactor MWCNT multi-walled carbon nanotube NHES nuclear hybrid energy storage NPP nuclear power plant NREL National Renewable Energy Laboratory ORNL Oak Ridge National Laboratory PAHTR prismatic-core advanced high temperature reactor PB-FHR pebble bed fluoride-salt-cooled high temperature reactor PCM phase changing material PF point focusing PTC parabolic trough collector SATES solid adsorption thermal energy storage SHTS sensible heat thermal storage SPT solar power tower SWCNT single-walled carbon nanotube TES thermal energy storage TGA thermal gravimetric analysis TCTS thermocline thermal storage TRISO tri-structural isotropic particle UCO uranium oxycarbide VHTR very high-temperature reactor 1 INTRODUCTION Global increase in population led to increase in energy consumption which in turn led to the environmental degradation. Statistics indicate that energy demand more than doubled in the last decade. This also led to a drastic increase in CO 2 emissions (around 35 billion tonnes as on 2021) causing global warming as power generation is still dependent on fossil fuels. 1 Hence the researchers worldover have focused on alternative sources of energy viz., solar, wind, biomass, geothermal, etc., besides developing novel and sustainable technologies for large scale energy storage. Trends in power consumption are encouraging in terms of shifting toward these renewable sources with lower dependency on fossil fuels though we need to depend on latter for few more decades. The energy emitted by the sun on earth is 4.1 × 10 17 J/h, which exceeds the annual global energy consumption (for the year 2001). 2 Hence, solar energy generated through concentrated solar power plants (CSPPs) is a promising solution to today's energy crisis. However, there often arises an un-co-ordinated mismatch between the energy demand and the energy produced as the alternative energy sources suffer from unpredictable fluctuations viz., variable sunshine period, cloud buffer, uneven wind flow, etc. The potential solution to this problem is development of efficient and sustainable energy storage technologies. Nuclear power plants (NPPs) are an interesting alternative to coal, natural gas, diesel, etc., as they are not only carbon-free but also reliable and economically viable. However, their inability to handle unprecedented load fluctuations and appropriate handling of fuel and generators in the nuclear reactors causing reactivity swings are the drawbacks of this technology. For this reason, energy storage is again required to trap that surplus energy generated during the hours of low demand for using it later when the power demand rises. 3 Therefore, a hybrid system consisting of a heat storage unit and a backup system is being explored along with CSPP or NPP as a sustainable solution to the growing electricity demand. 4 Molten salts are being explored as next generation materials for thermal energy storage (TES) owing to their high heat storage capacities, low vapor pressure, non-toxicity, low cost, high thermal stability, flexibility to modifications, and wide range of application. During off-peak hours, the salts can be heated and stored in an insulated container. 5 Thermal energy can then be converted to electric power using different heat engines. The cooled salt can then be sent to the storage tank again for reheating and continuing the cycle. Historically, heat has been stored in hot and cold water tanks to serve domestic and residential needs. Steam accumulators use the steam released from the NPPs as coolants and store the high-pressure steam as a saturated liquid. 6 The tanks made to store pressurized steam can store the same at high temperatures and are hence found in abundance in multiple parts of Europe and North America despite the potential hazards due to the high expansion coefficient of water resulting in leakages 7 and the closeness of the freezing and boiling points of water giving low operational temperature range. 8 Hybrid systems of solar and NPPs are also reported to be used to achieve higher thermal efficiencies in which solar heat is transmitted to nuclear steam to increase its temperature, and the required continuous heat is delivered via molten salts-based TES systems. The specific objectives of this review are to present: Different molten salts with necessary dopants prominently used as TES materials. Potential applications of molten salts in solar and NPPs. Comparative assessment of various TES technologies. Different configurations of solar and NPPs including hybrid versions. Modification protocols to improve the performance of molten salts using nanomaterials. Corrosion due to molten salts and its mitigation methods. Future challenges and concerns associated with molten salts. This review elaborately encompasses all aspects of molten salts and their usage as heat storage and transfer material for use at solar and NPPs. It starts with a comprehensive yet concise comparative analysis of various TES technologies followed by a discussion on energy storage by phase change materials (PCMs). Popular CSPP designs are presented focusing on their thermodynamic efficiencies and comparison factors. To facilitate heat transfer from one plant location to another, an intense review of heat transfer fluids (HTFs) is done. Furthermore, the motivation to use molten salts arises to store the heat carried by those HTFs, which is successively covered by this review. A wide variety of molten salt mixtures (secondary, tertiary, and even quaternary) are compared based on their thermodynamics and rheological properties like heat capacity, thermal conductivity, viscosity, specific gravity, and range of operating temperatures. These properties are found to be enhanced and thereby storage efficiency by nanoparticle doping. A detailed list of molten salts and their dopants are tabulated in the review. Nuclear TES, different nuclear reactors (MSR, LW-SMR, MHTGR, PAHTR, PB-FHR) used, types of fissile materials and energy storage systems they employ are also discussed in detail. A typical NPP can be inclusively modified to concatenate it with an efficient heat storage technique driven by molten salts. This system is presented elaborately as an nuclear hybrid energy storage (NHES) in this review. The heat storage section of this system uses molten salts in two ways—a two-tank direct design and a thermocline design, both of which are studied and compared based on the relevant parameters. Role of nanofluids to increase the heat storing capabilities of molten salts is discussed. The review finally concludes with the most imminent concerns regarding the usage of such technology at power plants and the future directions. The novelty of this article lies in the comprehensive and inclusive comparison of the many technologies available for TES and their working principles and methods of improving their efficiencies. The more novel hybrid techniques of energy storage are also discussed along with the application of molten salts in them. In order to increase heat storage properties of molten salts, several strategies are provided, and special focus is put on the latest methods associated with nano-modification of molten salts with dopants. A collection of dopants with their characteristics are enlisted and discussed in great depth. A very often over-looked topic of discussion is the problem of corrosion of molten salt storage tanks which is given heavy focus in the last few sections of the paper; their effects, severity, and mitigation strategies are discussed in detail. There has not been any review of molten salts as comprehensive and all-inclusive as this one in a long time. 9 , 10 Furthermore, most studies only consider thermal storage for solar energy, while this review presents energy storage for two alternative energy sources, solar and nuclear energy. 11 - 13 2 THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE TECHNOLOGIES There are two types of TES solutions for CSPPs: active and passive. The system is called an active type when the fluid that moves between the storage tanks is chosen as the storage medium. The system is called direct-active if the storage media also functions as the HTF. In the “indirect-active” type, dissimilar pairs of storage and heat transfer media are used with an additional requirement of a heat exchanger. When a solid is chosen as the storage medium, the HTF only flows through it to charge and discharge the battery. The term “passive” refers to such a type of system. Figure 1 shows various TES designs used at CSPPs. 14 Depending on short-term and long-term variations in solar energy availability and electricity demand, such CSPP-TES-integrated systems adopt a variety of operating strategies 15 : Buffering : A transient mode occupies over steam generators due to cloud cover or some meteorological activities that cause stoppage of optimum solar energy from reaching the collectors. Some HTFs possess just enough thermal inertia to help a plant in managing and working out through such buffer periods, however at a reduced efficiency, as a result of which shut-down of turbines is an unpreventable order. Extension of the delivery period : Peak solar radiation may not coincide with peak power demand. A considerable fraction of the energy accumulated when the solar energy received at its peak is stored and used at a later period of time during greater electricity demand or tariffs. Improving the annual capacity factor : Annual capacity factor is an important measure that compares plant's net electricity production vs the amount of energy it could have produced at its peak efficiency for the entire duration of time. The absence of a storage system lowers its capacity factor significantly. FIGURE 1 Open in figure viewer PowerPoint Types of thermal energy storage design. TES, thermal energy storage As discussed below, TES systems can be classified as sensible heat storage, latent heat storage, and thermochemical storage. 2.1 Sensible Heat Thermal Storage The energy is stored/released in sensible heat thermal storage (SHTS) systems by raising or lowering the storage medium's temperature. The desired thermodynamic and rheological attributes that the medium must possess are high thermal conductivity and heat capacity besides long-term thermal stability. Solid materials (eg, rocks, metals, concrete, bricks, etc.,) can resist extreme temperatures, without
